pull.title: doc: Rework internal and external links
pull.body:
Some minor changes:
* Move Bitcoin Core download link to the very top. *Reason:* The download link has nothing to do with the section that explains Bitcoin. Also, anyone quickly looking for the download link will find it faster.
* Add a new link to the doc folder. *Reason*: Apart from the documentation that is shipped with the binary software, the doc folder is the primary location for Bitcoin Core related documentation.
* Remove dead link to pdf. *Reason*: The pdf can be trivially found by asking a search engine.
* Remove reference to "build server". *Reason*: There is no "build server". The CI system is explained in the next sentence in detail.
* Remove dead? link to translation mailing list. *Reason*: The translation process is explained in `doc/translation_process.md`, no need to explain it in detail in the main readme.

events.message: doc: Rework internal and external links

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #20976 (doc: fix broken link to whitepaper in README by ben-kaufman)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

ACK 77772a1b809e443a6861ee49009ff8bc55cff9c3

> Remove dead? link to translation mailing list. Reason: The translation process is explained in doc/translation_process.md, no need to explain it in detail in the main readme.

Good find. I can't even remember anymore when we used that list.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,9 +17,7 @@ with no central authority: managing transactions and issuing money are carried
 out collectively by the network. Bitcoin Core is the name of open source
 software which enables the use of this currency.
 
-For more information, as well as an immediately usable, binary version of
-the Bitcoin Core software, see https://bitcoincore.org/en/download/, or read the
-[original whitepaper](https://bitcoincore.org/bitcoin.pdf).
+For more information read the original Bitcoin whitepaper.
comments.body: isn't that a bit flimsy? It's not so hard to game Google rankings (and you can always buy ads, too), so googling "original Bitcoin whitepaper" could really give you anything. At least a footnote or something with bibliographic information (such as it is) would be nice, or maybe a md5sum of the "real" whitepaper, if that is feasible

comments.body: Crazy idea: what about adding instructions (or a script) on how to fetch the whitepaper directly from the UTXO set, as described e.g. by jb55 in https://bitcoinhackers.org/@jb55/105595146491662406 ("eat your own dogfood" ;-))

comments.body:
> or maybe a md5sum of the "real" whitepaper, if that is feasible

Inb4 content-addressed storage (e.g. IPFS).

In any case, something like that could be added later, let's remove the broken link.

comments.body: Maybe there could be an extensive stack exchange question or documentation file that explains where and how to get the whitepaper and how to check it against a hashsum? If needed we could link to that. Though, I think this can be done in a follow-up. And if your search engine was bought to redirect the traffic, you might not find this repo in the first place ;)

comments.body:
Apparently it is actually on IPFS. [gateway link here](https://gateway.ipfs.io/ipfs/QmRA3NWM82ZGynMbYzAgYTSXCVM14Wx1RZ8fKP42G6gjgj)
Users of [some browsers](https://github.com/ipfs/in-web-browsers) like Brave can use the IPFS link directly and don't  need the gateway.

@michaelfolkson sort of ! unfortunately it uses the blocktrail API instead of bitcoin core RPC, i prefer that if we send people on a puzzle to get it, they'd at least learn to use our APIs along the way  :smile: 

(maybe a matter of adding an answer, though)
